To the Editor: Having recently lunched at the Grand Vefour, I can second Sarah Ferrell's appraisal of the quality of its food and service ("Dining a Deux, Splendidly," July 3). And it doesn't have to carry such a price tag.

We had wanted to dine there for years but were wary of the cost and so decided to try lunch instead of dinner. We made a reservation a week in advance, and I asked if we could be seated at Colette's table.

We presented ourselves promptly at 1 P.M. The maitresse d' seemed to be expecting us, because when I gave her my name she didn't refer to a reservation list. She took the canvas bag I was carrying and did not give me a check for it. Then she said something to a waiter who took us directly to a very good table. I was quite impressed with such a smooth operation and then I remembered, I had asked for Colette's table. Sure enough we found a brass plate with her name.

The service began just as described but when the wine steward approached us with the list, I announced in my serviceable French that we would be having mineral water. He asked, "Uniquement?" and the expression on his face led me to believe we had fallen from grace.
On the contrary, the Perrier was brought in a wine cooler and no fewer than four waiters came to fill our glasses during our lunch.

Any sign that we lacked for something and a waiter was immediately at our side. And so it went without a hitch, the procession of petits fours, the cheese platter, the dessert, the coffee, the chocolates etc. Quel luxe!
The bill for the two of us was $140, but such service inspired us to leave a good tip in addition to the 15 percent service compris. VINCENT J. MENDOLA Huntington, L. I.
